Force Directed Graphs are node and link visualizations. The graph looks at the attractive forces acting on joined nodes versus the repelling forces of nodes that do not have a connection. The end result is a springy and interactive graph.
analysis: By the nature of how force direction works, datums form groupings by the number of and commonality of connections. These graphs can offer insights and visually assist users in detecting patterns and relationships. When used with a large network of information, this visualization can be used to tell a story. The interactivity of force directed graphs is also an additional positive quality.

summary: Chord diagrams are used to display relationships of data in matrix form. The outside circle is labelled with groupings, called nodes, that are then in turn connected by arcs, or arc connections. The arcs more readable than straight lines would be and are created with Bezier curves. The thickness of these arcs is correlated with the values of the connection it represents. Color is often used to show the directionality of the data.
analysis: A seasoned data visualization consumer understands the significance of color,positioning, arc size and groupings within a chord diagram. Any less-informed individual would be easily confused with the amount of data being presented.
